intro: Islaya copiapoides var. pseudomollendensis, commonly known as the Copiapó islaya, is a succulent plant native to the Atacama Desert in Chile. It is characterized by its fleshy, cylindrical stems that store water, allowing it to survive in arid conditions. The plant produces small, star-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale yellow, blooming during the cooler months. Its leaves are reduced to small, scale-like structures, a common adaptation in desert plants. This variety is closely related to other species in the Islaya genus, sharing similar morphological traits and ecological adaptations.
